title: Synthetic Recap
body:
WASHINGTON — On a night when the hardwood floor of the Capital Centre felt like a stage for one man’s masterpiece, Chris Webber of the Washington Bullets delivered a performance for the ages against his former team.

In a thrilling 113-105 victory over the Sacramento Kings, Webber was utterly dominant, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 45 points. From the opening tip, he was unstoppable, operating with a blend of power and finesse that the Kings had no answer for. He was not merely scoring; he was authoring a statement, each basket a punctuation mark in a story of revenge and ascendance against the club that drafted him.

The Bullets needed every ounce of his historic output. The Kings, led by Mitch Richmond’s 27 points, fought tenaciously, turning the contest into a back-and-forth affair. But every time Sacramento threatened to seize momentum, Webber had a response—a thunderous dunk in traffic, a silky jumper from the elbow, or a relentless pursuit of an offensive board.

His final line was staggering: 45 points, 11 rebounds, and 4 assists on 18-of-29 shooting. He was the engine, the focal point, and ultimately, the hero. While teammate Calbert Cheaney provided crucial support with 20 points, the night belonged unequivocally to Webber.

In securing the win, Webber did more than just lead his team to two points in the standings; he carved his name into the Bullets' record books and delivered one of the most spectacular individual performances the NBA would see all season, a virtuoso act that left no doubt about his superstar arrival.
